title: Roquefort row: purists turn air blue over pasteurised rival to France's 'king' of cheeses
text:
Defenders of genuine roquefort, France’s famed salty blue cheese, have seen red over a cheaper, pasteurised lookalike they say is eating into already dwindling sales and which they want banned.

The row is the latest in a long-running battle between purists and industrial dairy groups they say are sapping the foundations of traditional cheesemaking by supplanting raw milk with milder tasting, pasteurised produce.

Dubbed “the king of cheeses”, roquefort is France’s oldest appellation.

Production follows strict guidelines in place since 1925 and which oblige producers to use the milk of freely grazing sheep from the surrounding area. All cheese production must take place in the town of Roquefort-sur-Soulzon, where the cheese has been made in the same vein for 1,000 years.

While family producers still exist, around 70 per cent of genuine roquefort made according to “protected designation of origin”, or PDO, rules is produced by Société des Caves, a brand owned by the world’s biggest dairy group, Lactalis.

Société recently launched a cheese called bleu de brebis (Ewes’ Blue) which uses pasteurised milk, is cheaper and milder in taste. It sports the same brand name and the green packaging is very similar to the original.
